questions.text: A 60-year-old man came to the Ophthalmology OPD with complaints of a diminution of vision. He was a daily wage worker who works in a factory and does welding mainly. He is also a chronic smoker. The patient also claims that he can read the newspaper without his reading glasses which was not possible until recently. Which among the following statements about the Diagnosis is NOT TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: The above diagnosis is Nuclear Cataract

options.label: B
options.text: The central fibres harden while the cortical fibres are relatively unaffected

options.label: C
options.text: The colour of the nucleus becomes dark due to pigmented protein deposition

options.label: D
options.text: Near vision is improved because of progressive Hypermetropia

questions.correct_answer: D. Near vision is improved because of progressive Hypermetropia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Near vision is improved because of progressive Hypermetropia Near vision improves relatively in this patient because of progressive Myopia (not Hypermetropia) It affects distant vision much more than Near vision. It is more in the daytime or under Bright light.

Highyeild:

As the Refractive index of the lens increases , there is progressive Myopia which relatively betters Near vision while worsening distant vision.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . The features in the clinical vignette suggest that the patient is suffering from cataracts and symptoms suggesting "Second sight" (able to read a newspaper without his glasses) help to conclude that it is a case of a Nuclear Type Of Cataract. Option: B . In this type of Cataract, there is a tendency for the Nuclear fibres to harden/sclerosed Option : C. As it progresses the nucleus becomes dark brown or red because of pigmented protein deposition . These proteins are derived from tryptophan due to exposure to sunlight.

questions.text: Cataracts are losing the transparency of the lens occurring due to various changes in the protein content of the lens. The two main types of senile cataracts are Nuclear cataracts and Cortical cataracts. Which of the following options about the differences between the two are TRUE Cortical Type is due to Overhydration while Nuclear Type is due to dehydration There is an increase in the Refractive index in cortical Type while a decrease in Nuclear Type Cortical type shows a progressive Hypermetropia while the Nuclear variant shows progressive Myopia Second sight is seen in both types of senile Cataracts Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: A
options.text: A, b, c and d are true

options.label: B
options.text: Only a and c are true

options.label: C
options.text: Only b and d are true

options.label: D
options.text: Only a,b and c are true

questions.correct_answer: B. Only a and c are true
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only a and c are true The statements a and c are true while b and d are false. The Peripheral fibres in the cortical Cataract are affected while it is spared in Nuclear Cataract and in the same way central fibres are hardened in nuclear Cataracts while spared in cortical variants. A cortical variant of senile cataract occurs due to Overhydration and accumulation of fluid Nuclear Type is due to dehydration There is a decrease in the Refractive index in the cortical Type while an increase in the Nuclear variant The cortical type shows progressive Hypermetropia while the Nuclear variant shows progressive Myopia. Hence only the Nuclear Type Of Cataract shows the feature of Second sight and not the cortical variant.

questions.text: An elderly patient comes to the ophthalmology OPD with a diminution of vision. He also complains that he can see more than one image with the same eye. The ophthalmologist suspects Cataracts. Which of the following options regarding the mechanism and the stage of the Cataract is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: This finding is called uniocular polyopia

options.label: B
options.text: It is seen in the Incipient Stage of Cortical Cataract

options.label: C
options.text: It is due to different Refractive indexes in the same lens due to water droplets

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It shows progressive Myopia Progressive Myopia is observed in the Nuclear variant of Cataract (not the Incipient Stage of Cortical Cataract)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B. The above Clinical vignette where the patient complains that he can see many images in the same eye is called Uniocular Polyopia. It is seen mainly in the Incipient Stage of Cortical Cataracts Option: C. The fluid starts to accumulate in the lens and in this early stage, it accumulates as water droplets scattered in the content of the lens. Hence there is irregular refraction due to different Refractive indices in each region of the lens.

questions.text: Given below are a few symptoms of Acquired cataracts. Match the following symptoms with their appropriate Pathogenesis. Select the correct answer given below code:

options.label: A
options.text: I - d, II - a, III - b, IV - c

options.label: B
options.text: I - a, II - b, III - c, IV - d

options.label: C
options.text: I - d, II - c, III - b, IV - a

options.label: D
options.text: I - d, II - b, III - a, IV – c

questions.correct_answer: A. I - d, II - a, III - b, IV - c
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I - d, II - a, III - b, IV - c Symptoms - Pathogenesis Glare - Due to increased light scattering Monocular Diplopia - Water droplets in it have a different Refractive index than the normal areas Second Sight - Increased Refractive index of the nucleus thereby causing myopia Reduced Visual Acuity - Lens transparency is reduced

Highyeild:

The table given below shows various symptoms of Acquired Cataracts and their Pathogenesis Symptom Pathogenesis Type of Cataract Frequent change of glasses Rapid change in refractive index of the lens Cortical or nuclear Reduced visual acuity usually gradual, painless, progressive Reduction in transparency of the lens All types Second sight or myopic shift Change in refractive index of the nucleus causes index myopia, improving near vision Nuclear cataract Loss of ability to see objects in bright sunlight, blinded by light of oncoming headlamps when driving at night Loss of contrast sensitivity, which is greater at higher spatial frequencies; constriction of pupil cuts off peripheral vision from noncataractous area Posterior subcapsular Monocular diplopia or polyopia Cortical spoke opacities in conjunction with water clefts that form radial wedges containing a fluid of lower refractive index than the surrounding lens Cortical cataract (spoke or cuneiform) Glare Increased scattering of light Cortical and posterior subcapsular Coloured halos around light Irregularity in the refractive index of different parts of the lens Cortical cataract Colour shift (becomes more obvious after surgery) Blue end of the spectrum is absorbed more by the cataractous lens Nuclear Visual field loss Generalized reduction in sensitivity due to loss of transparency All types
